On 7/31/07, Nat Pryce <nat.pryce@...> wrote:
>  And, may I add, that =
a technical solution to social problem is a poor
>  substitute for a social=
 solution to the social problem.

I'm not sure I understand that.

Using a =
sound implementation for a singleton (e.g. dependency
injection) is similar=
 to leveraging the compiler to minimize mistakes:
 I'd rather trust the com=
piler to enforce a good practice than vague
social recommendations that ris=
k to be ignored for various reasons
(and even by the best developers).

>  =
If members of the team don't understand the architecture then tech
>  huddl=
es and a big visible architecture diagram can help.

This is a very idealis=
tic view of things.  In teams of dozens of
programmers of various age and s=
eniority levels scattered over
multiple time zones, mentoring and diagrams =
only go so far.  The only
way to guarantee that things don't break is to le=
verage your
programming language to make sure that any infraction will simp=
ly not
compile.

>  If the class names don't express the idea that there sh=
ould only be
>  one of a class in the production code then a tech huddle to=
 agree on a
>  system of names and a refactoring session can help.

Maybe f=
or very tiny open source projects, but certainly not in
general, in my expe=
rience...
